answers.text: can God create a stone so heavy that he cannot lift it

qas.question: What is another term for the Omnipotence paradox?
Does either outcome of the Paradox of the Stone prove the existence of God?

answers.text: God is not omnipotent. A being that is not omnipotent, though, is not God

qas.question: What shows God is not omnipotent if he creates a stone that he cannot lift?

answers.text: there is something that he cannot do

qas.question: What must God be, in order to be a Supreme Being?
What paradox states that if a god can't create a stone so heavy he can't lift it?
What does the Paradox of the Stone posit?
What does it mean if a God is not omnipotent?
Are there any answers to the Pradox of the Stone?

plausible_answers.text: can God create a stone so heavy that he cannot lift it?

qas.question: What question does the theological model paradox ask?
How many arguments about God's power prove he exists?
What is a term for the existence of God?
What model proves that God can lift a stone he creates?
If God can create a stone he can't lift, what proves he exists?

context: According to the <b11_0>Omnipotence paradox<b11_0/> or '<a1_0><a5_0>Paradox of the Stone<a5_0/><a1_0/>', <a0_0><b9_0>can God create a stone so heavy that he cannot lift it<a0_0/>?<b9_0/> Either he can or he can’t. If he can’t, the argument goes, then <a3_0>there is something that he cannot do<a3_0/>, namely create the stone, and therefore <a6_0>he is not <a4_0>omnipotent<a6_0/><a4_0/>. If he can, it continues, then there is also something that he cannot do, namely lift the stone, and therefore he is not omnipotent. Either way, then, <a2_0>God is not omnipotent. A being that is not omnipotent, though, <a7_0>is not God<a7_0/><a2_0/>, according to <b12_0>many <b13_0>theological models<b13_0/><b12_0/>. Such a God, therefore, does not exist. <a8_0><b10_0>Several<b10_0/><a8_0/> answers to this paradox have been proposed.
